awd_titl_txt: EarthCube Data Capabilities: Collaborative Proposal: Reducing Time-To-Science in the Earth Sciences: Annotations to foster convergence, inclusion, and credit
awd_abstract_narration:
The long term sustainability of federally funded research depends on the discovery, accessibility and reuse of data.  However, data and research products are often stored in different locations. This makes it challenging to find and integrate related data. This project helps support the discovery of related but distributed research products for Earth science and natural history data. Researches will have a way to link data resources, add context, or provide additional information about data, software and publications.  Researchers use this system to create annotations that link resources using unique identifiers.  Over time, these links connect to create a network of data resources. This project will support the development of the underlying database, a user interface for access and discovery, and a number of documentation tools and workshops to help support the ongoing development and sustainability of the Throughput database.The broader impacts of this project include the engagement of early career researchers and the better sharing of data and other research products in the Earth sciences.

Improved discoverability of data, metadata and services is a need shared across the geosciences. A barrier that increases "time-to-science" in Earth Science research is the difficulty of integrating individual observations, concepts, data models, and statistical techniques across subfields. The Throughput Annotation Engine (TAE) offers a solution to the challenge of managing interdisciplinary workflows by providing multiple points of entry to access, annotate and interact with data, and to link code, data, publications, or other elements to one another. The TAE will support adoption as part of a system of systems, linking outside users to data repositories, and providing data stewards a degree of flexibility in deciding how to manage new information: whether to incorporate information in annotations into their data models, or to access and report annotations using the Throughput API. Throughput improves credit for data, software and documentation by providing a mechanism to track use and implementation across a range of publications and online resources, and will provide a new set of citation tools based on FORCE11 recommendations. Linked annotations in the TAE support the generation of metrics for research infrastructure beyond standard publication metrics. The Cookbook will allow individuals and communities to identify programmatic workflows, and link them to community data resources. The Cookbook will provide researchers with access to community best-practices, and, by leveraging ORCID user credentials, to individuals engaged in the development of documentation and workflows. Throughput offers a user-centered solution to deepening and densifying connections among the many nodes in the emerging linked data ecosystem of scientists, data, software services, journals, and funders.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Integrative and Collaborative Education and Research (ICER)

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
This grant provided funds for development of software and improvements to data systems that allow better use of data produced by scientific research from projects involving drilling and analysis of drill core samples, documentation and community outreach for the software, and support for training of early-career researchers in leveraging their scientific work for maximum benefit to the public. 

More than a hundred of these research projects generate new data every year, which focus on scientific topics including:

  • Changes in climate, Earth processes, and ecosystems from 3 billion years ago to present
  • Groundwater hydrology and water resources
  • Microbial life in soil and rock
  • Processes that change rock into soil
  • Fault systems and earthquake processes
  • Volcano processes
  • Geothermal systems and energy resources
  • Plate tectonics
  • Impact processes from asteroids and comets 

Data from these projects include site survey data, performance data describing the drilling or coring process, borehole geophysical survey data, core logs (visual lithologic descriptions), core photographs, microscopic analyses, and several types of automated core scans. 

The software and related improvements to data systems allow all such data to be more easily accessed and shared among data systems throughout the scientific community, and to provide a means to create notes about earlier data when new findings are made. These notes could inform other scientists or the public about data that are particularly useful, or which have been shown to be inaccurate through further study, or other topics that help scientists to use existing data most effectively to make new discoveries. 

The primary work of design and implementation of the software, and other project components, was developed by partner institutions through their own associated collaborative grants. 

The University of Minnesota team developed standardized formats for each data type; identified and (whenever possible) filled gaps in workflows and systems that comprise the necessary data flows; and worked toward implementing a system to host and distribute existing and new scientific drilling data and metadata generated at the Continental Scientific Drilling Facility, and to enable the establishment of linkages with other community data systems for interoperability.  

Together, the developments supported by this project make it easier for scientists and anyone with access to the internet to discover, inspect, and visualize the data. The software also makes it possible to more easily re-use the data, to check earlier scientific findings, and to answer new scientific questions in the future. This maximizes the value of the data and drill core samples produced by nearly a thousand past projects and allows scientists to answer new kinds of questions using existing data without the need to perform field work to collect new samples. New discoveries can be made, at the lowest possible cost.


Last Modified: 01/13/2025
Modified by: Anders J Noren
